Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Epigenomics of Andean High-Altitude Adaptation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
At high altitudes, most people show a decrease in blood oxygen levels, a spike in blood pressure, and increased heart and breathing rates. However, long-term resident populations at high altitudes have unique physiological adaptations that allow them to survive and reproduce in this extreme niche. This project will examine epigenetic changes, specifically changes in DNA methylation, to understand how being born and raised at high altitude affects human biology. For many years biological anthropologists have sought to understand the heritable genetic variants that allow survival at high altitudes, and this project is significant in moving from a genetic to an epigenetic focus. Unlike high altitude gene variants that an individual either inherits or not, DNA methylation can change during an individual's lifetime because it undergoes reprogramming during early development and is therefore susceptible to the effects of the environment. Project findings will contribute to our understanding of how early development influences adaptive phenotypes to extreme environments. Identification of epigenetic changes in the hypoxia (low-oxygen) response pathway may also inform future research on the role of hypoxia in cancer etiology, cardiac ischemia, and stroke. The project will also support undergraduate and graduate training in laboratory research methods.

Whole-genome and gene-specific DNA methylation signatures will be measured in one high altitude population from the Andes - the Peruvian Quechua. Study participants (n= 601) have been recruited to represent different high-altitude developmental exposures including: 1) born and raised at low altitude (n=150), 2) born at high altitude and moved to low altitude during adolescence (n = 150), 3) born and raised at high altitude (n=301). This project builds on the investigators' strong foundation of research to understand the genetic changes that contribute to high-altitude adaptation in this same population. This project allows the assessment of how genetics and epigenetics interact to create the Andean altitude-adaptive phenotype. Understanding this interaction has implications for the study of high-altitude adaptation specifically and human biological adaptation more generally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
High-altitude adaptation is a strong example of natural selection operating on the human genome. Physiological and genetic adaptations have been documented in populations with a history of living at high altitude including Andeans, Tibetans, and Ethiopians. These populations display unique evolutionary adaptations allowing them to overcome hypoxic (low oxygen) stress. Importantly, altitude-adaptive phenotypes likely are not determined solely by genetic variation. Growth and development at high altitude contribute to altitude-adaptive traits. Among Andeans in particular, research has shown that Andeans have greater lung volumes than sea-level residents and higher arterial oxygen saturation during exercise than Andeans who were born and raised at low altitude. Epigenetic modifications are mitotically and in some cases meiotically heritable changes to gene expression that do not involve changes to the DNA sequence. They have been proposed to contribute to the process of adaptation. However, the role of the epigenome in high-altitude adaptation is not well understood.

We used a migrant study design wherein Andeans from three different lifetime exposures to altitude were recruited for participation in Peru. They included: 1) Quechua high altitude residents from Cerro de Pasco, Peru at 4,338 m above sea-level. 2) Quechua migrants born at altitude but who migrated permanently to sea-level in Lima, Peru (0 m). 3) Quechua low altitude residents who were born, raised, and reside at sea level in Lima, Peru (0 m). Thus, this third study group is composed of second-generation down-migrants who have had no developmental exposure to high altitude over the course of their lifetime, but their parents and both sets of grandparents were born at an altitude > 3,000 m.

We performed an epigenome-wide association study (EWAS) in 113 Peruvian Quechua from the three study groups to identify regions of the epigenome that differed based on altitude exposure. Preliminary findings show significant DNA methylation differences between 1) Quechua who were born and reside at high altitude versus low altitude and 2) Quechua who were born and raised at low altitude and migrant Quechua. These significant regions were found in genes that have been associated with the HIF pathway, pulmonary hypertension, fatty acid oxidation, blood pressure, and glycolysis. We also explored epigenetic aging among this cohort. Individuals with the longest lifetime exposure to high altitude showed accelerated epigenetic aging compared to participants born at low altitude. Furthermore, hemoglobin concentration was positively associated with accelerated epigenetic age.

Our findings demonstrate that DNA methylation could be affected by exposure to high altitude, and may play a role in the ability of Andeans to adapt to this environment and protect them from high-altitude associated conditions. Overall, this dissertation research demonstrates that the environment can have a profound impact on epigenetic modifications.

Broader impacts included the training of several undergraduate students in wet-lab techniques and statistical analysis.  Furthermore, this study continued research collaboration with Peruvian scientists.
